sp.speaker: L. Mar.
sp.p: However highly you may rate it, ſir, there is a degree of politeneſs in leſſening the value of what we beſtow.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Circumſtances vary caſes, niece; there are ſome things we ſhould not depreciate.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: I rate the gift ſo far above my worth, ſir, that nothing ſhall ever tempt me to accept of it.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Miſs Lawſon, you are the very paragon of humility; tho' I confeſs I think you are right not to be teized with ſuch a diſagreeable animal; a thing, that by pretending to imitate human ſpeech, puts one out of humour with the ſound of our own voice, as much as a monkey does with our ſpecies; I hate parrots, and monkeys.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes, but you love fops, and coxcombs, don't you? Let me tell you, madam, your tongue runs before your wit, you don't know what you are abuſing.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: I ſhou'd be ſorry to find fault with any thing you lik'd, ſir, but I thought it was merely as a naturaliſt, that you kept ſuch a number of parrots; I did not think it was for the pleaſure of hearing them talk.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I can tell you, madam, I wou'd rather hear them chatter, than you.

sp.speaker: L. Mar.
sp.p: Yet they ſometimes caſt reflections, mal a propos, as well as my ſiſter, ſir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
Pray, ladies, let me draw breath.—Was there ever ſuch a couple of vixens!— (aſide to Emily) Don't
mind them, miſs, but conſider what I have ſaid; I am ſure it is intirely for your good I ſpeak. You don't know what a vaſt collection of pretty things I have, and they ſhall all be yours.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Where things are in themſelves indifferent, ſir, perſuaſions and temptations may avail; but where our reſolutions are founded in reaſon, nothing can or ſhou'd alter them.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Huſh, huſh, miſs, not a word more upon this ſubject, I have a great deal of buſineſs upon my hands; but pray, miſs, do think about it. I'll get you a very fine noeſgay to-morrow, I'll pull my paul diack tulip for you; the root coſt me twenty pounds, but you ſhall have it. Sure you won't be cruel to me now! Don't ſay one word, for I muſt run, and you ſhall have the tulip at any rate.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: Your ſervant, ladies, was not that Mr. Belmont that left you? I ſuppoſe he has been entertaining you with ſome of his curioſities?

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: I think he is himſelf a greater curioſity, than any in his collection, my lord, but I fancy he has a mind to diſpoſe of them all together, and means to give a bargain of them to Miſs Lawſon.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: He has done me the honour to offer me abundance of rarities, madam, but I am not diſpoſed to receive favours that I cannot return; therefore his treaſures are all ſafe for me

sp.speaker: L. Mar.
sp.p: I fancy he loads his gifts with hard conditions, and would perſuade you to accept himſelf along with them. Is it not ſo, Miſs Lawſon?

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: I congratulate you on your conqueſt, Emily; your eyes can do wonders, it ſeems, and light up ſparks in dying embers.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p:
I rather think, my lord, that Mr. Belmont's flame is of that kind, which dying fires emit, to ſhew their near extinction; and the faint blaze has, but by
accident, caſt it's pale light on me; any other object might have been brighten'd by the ſame glimmer.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: You wrong my uncle's taſte; I have not heard of his propoſing to marry any lady theſe five years. Before that time, he uſed to be generally in love twice a year, and had his ſummer and winter paſſions, which he conſtantly chang'd with his cloaths for the ſeaſon.

sp.speaker: L. Mar.
sp.p: I am ſurpriz'd, my lord, that among ſuch a variety of miſtreſſes, he never found one that wou'd marry him; his perſon muſt have been tolerable, when he was young; his family and fortune unexceptionable.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: Be aſſur'd, ſiſter, that was not the caſe; but by the time he had brought the lady to think favourably of him, he began to diſcover ſome imperfection in her. Perhaps her noſe was a hair's breadth longer or ſhorter than it ſhou'd be, according to the exact rules of proportion; a foot, or a finger, perhaps, diſguſted him; on which, he immediately quitted his purſuit, and went in ſearch of another model.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: It is happy the men are not ſo nice, now-a-days, or we ſhou'd never be able to fix a lover.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: I fancy, Louiſa, that muſt be at all times a difficult matter to accompliſh; a fine woman will, doubtleſs, captivate many, but there is ſomething more than beauty, neceſſary to preſerve her conqueſt over one.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: Why, ſo they ſay, my lord; but I proteſt I can't credit it. It is impoſſible, I think, for a woman to loſe her power, while ſhe retains her beauty.

sp.speaker: L. Mar.
sp.p: A moment's recollection muſt furniſh you with ſuch a number of inſtances to contradict your aſſertion, Louiſa, that I'm afraid the argument will drop, on your conviction; and I ſhou'd like vaſtly to have it carried on.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: O! never fear, we'll keep it up; but I won't admit of odds; 'tis only with my brother I argue.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: Well then, I grant, that while beauty laſts, it will always have admirers. But theſe, Louiſa, are but pageants to a conqueror; the triumph muſt be found at home, in the heartfelt love and eſteem of a man of ſenſe and honour.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: True, my lord, but that ſame beauty, that cauſes admiration and attention in other men, will neceſſarily preſerve our huſband's love.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: By no means, Louiſa; poſſeſſion damps the ardor of deſire; merit alone can keep the flame alive, and hinder every wanton gale from blowing it abroad; that, like the veſtal fire, muſt be preſerv'd by conſtant watching.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: By your account, my lord, a married woman has juſt as bad a life as a veſtal, if her whole time is to be ſpent in keeping one ſpark alive.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: I will allow her taſk is full as arduous, tho' more pleaſing. Men are naturally inconſtant; and a huſband may ſometimes ſee a woman fairer than his wife; but 'tis her fault, if in the whole circle, he can find one that ſo well deſerves his love; whoſe temper, manners, conduct, and behaviour, are ſo much ſuited to his ſentiments; who knows no wiſh or will, but to pleaſe him—theſe charms, the homelieſt woman may acquire; without them, the faireſt form that ever ſtruck our eyes, cannot retain one heart.

sp.speaker: L. Mar.
sp.p: Indeed, my lord, we are vaſtly obliged to you for this excellent leſſon; and ought to think ourſelves extremely happy in ſuch a ſenſible and kind inſtructor.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: You make me ſo, as I hope that theſe ſlight hints I have thrown out, may be of uſe to you. But why ſo grave, Miſs Lawſon? I hope I have not made you melancholy.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: I have heard your lordſhip, with the utmoſt pleaſure, and moſt ſincerely wiſh, that my whole ſex had done ſo too.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: I think tho', we ought not to wiſh that the other ſex had heard his lordſhip; it wou'd make ſome of them horridly inſolent.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: Be aſſur'd, Louiſa, that I have only ſpoke the general opinion of every rational man. But a truce with the ſubject; for I flatter myſelf, you have no need of any other monitor, but your own ſenſe and virtue. Pray, Miſs Lawſon, do you know a Mr. Freeman?

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: No, my lord.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: She ſeems not at all embarraſs'd. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: L Loui
sp.p: [aſide to Lady Mary] What can he mean?

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: Is he of your acquaintance, Lady Mary? Or of yours, Louiſa?

sp.speaker: L. Mar.
sp.p: I am not at all acquainted with him, my lord.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: One knows ſuch a number of people, by meeting them in public, that it is impoſſible to remember names; we might, perhaps, have met ſuch a perſon at Soho, or at Almack's. Siſter, ſhall we go ſee my aunt? I think ſome one ſaid ſhe was not well.—Will you come, Miſs Lawſon?

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: I'll wait on your ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: Stop a moment, Emily, I have but juſt time to tell you, that your father is arriv'd, and I have ſeen him.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Is he in health, my lord? I greatly fear this haſty journey may have injur'd him; that wou'd compleat my wretchedneſs.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: Quiet your fears, he is in perfect health, and has promis'd to give his conſent to your marrying Sir Charles Somerville; or, in ſhort, whomever elſe you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: How happy wou'd this kindneſs once have made me! now 'tis an aggravation of my ſorrow, and comes like a reprieve, when execution's paſt. Yet ſtill I thank my father; he will not preſs me then to the deteſted march he once propos'd. O let me fly to him, my lord, and on theſe trembling knees receive his bleſſing.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: You muſt not think of ſeeing him this night; to-morrow he'll be here, that's time enough. I flatter myſelf, that a very little time will ſerve to clear this myſtery.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: O grant it heaven! let my poor heart be eas'd of this ſad load, which even imputed guilt can cauſe, and conſcious innocence but ill ſuſtain; then let me yield that heart to undivided, and unceaſing ſorrow, for my loſt Somerville.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: Dry up your tears, he may not yet be loſt. I now intreat you will, for a little time, be guided by me; I wou'd not have you ſuffer my ſiſters to perceive any change in your looks, tho' I hope there will ſoon be a material one in your ſituation.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: I ſhall endeavour to obey your lordſhip.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: What am I now to think? that Emily's innocent, I muſt believe; I took her on a ſudden, unprepar'd, and yet ſhe anſwer'd with ſuch calm indifference as common queſtions uſually produce. I'll keep a watchful eye upon Louiſa; ſhe was not calm, nor did ſhe anſwer fairly to the queſtion.—I fear the ſtain comes nearer than I thought; and yet I cannot think ſo meanly of my conduct towards her, as to ſuppoſe ſhe fears me; why then ſhou'd ſhe conceal the moſt important action of her life from her ſincereſt friend?
sp.l: But men and women both have their capri •• .
We deal too hardly, when we call it vice.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Young Freeman's lodgings; he is diſcover'd on a couch, with a book in his hand.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.

q.l: " IS ſhe not more than painting can expreſs,
" Or youthful poets fancy when they love?"

sp.p: 'Tis now near ten; at eleven, I'll make another glorious effort to carry off the prize. Her laſt words were, "Pray be gone, this inſtant, tho' you ſhou'd return."—Dear creature! and ſhall I not accept thy gentle invitation? I'll quarter her arms on my chariot, as if ſhe were an heireſs. Lord, how it will fret the ſober family in Lombard-ſtreet, who have only a cypher on their coach.
Are my cloaths come?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Yes, pleaſe your honour.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Get out my white and ſilver, prepare every thing to dreſs, and ſtep to the next coach-maker; I want a chariot and ſix flying horſes, to be got ready in half an hour: tell the fellow, I ſhall deal with him for an elegant equipage, in a few days. [Exit Ralph.
[Aſide.] What brings him here? He is worſe than the devil, and comes before the termination of his contract.

sp.speaker: E. Free.
sp.p: Well, brother, have you ſeen the lady?

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Why, Jack, I thought you men of buſineſs were more exact? Do you think I can't hold it 'till Monday, that you call upon me before the three days are out? This wou'd be enough to hurt a man's credit in the city; and why it ſhou'd not be deem'd a mark of inſolvency, at this end of the town, I can't conceive.

sp.speaker: E. Free.
sp.p:
As you ſeem to think a citizen has no ideas but what relate to trade, I ſhall, upon your own premiſes, explain my viſit. When we have but a ſlight
opinion of our debtor, and find him tardy, we think it neceſſary to obſerve his motions: but where a man of honour is concerned, tho' we may doubt his power, we don't ſuſpect his principles, and therefore never watch his motions.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Which is, in plain Engliſh, to ſay, you look upon me as a ſcoundrel.—Votre ſerviteur, tres humble.

sp.speaker: E. Free.
sp.p: You have drawn this ſarcaſm upon yourſelf, by preſuming too haſtily to explain my motives for this viſit; the irkſomneſs of which gives but a bad idea of your integrity. Thoſe who act fairly, need not fear inſpection.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Indeed, brother, you ſeem to me quite on the qui vive, always in a diſpoſition to quarrel, which is a mighty improper temper of mind to viſit a lover in, who ſhou'd be all tun'd to harmony and joy.

sp.speaker: E. Free.
sp.p: The mind ſhou'd be at peace within itſelf, to feel thoſe charming ſenſations; they muſt ariſe from conſcious worth—not even the power of beauty can awake them, in mean, diſhoneſt hearts; I therefore ſhou'd rejoice, that you were capable of feeling their happy influence.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Ay, now you talk ſomething like a brother, and in return for your good nature, I will acquaint you, that I am this moment preparing to viſit my charmer.

sp.speaker: E. Free.
sp.p: Surely you have been much to blame, to delay ſo long; this is not a proper time of night, to wait upon a woman of faſhion.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Not for a tradeſmen, I grant you, but we pretty fellows are welcome at all hours.

sp.speaker: E. Free.
sp.p: Prithee, Harry, lay by the coxcomb, and tho' you don't act, ſpeak at leaſt, like a rational creature; what cou'd prevent your viſiting the lady, all this evening; upon the plan I propos'd, and you agreed to?

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p:
Why, really, Jack, you are ſo very impetuous, you won't give a man time to anſwer your
why's, and your wherefores; but if it will ſatisfy you, I did wait on the lady, this very evening; and am, by her appointment, to ſee her again this night. I then hope to prevail on her to ſtep into an hired equipage with me, and for the reſt of my life, to drive in my own.

sp.speaker: E. Free.
sp.p: I don't underſtand you, ſure; is ſhe ſo romantically ſmitten, that ſhe can't wait a few days, 'till her friends and yours have adjuſted matters for her honour and ſecurity? There can be no doubt, that my father will gladly receive her as his daughter, and make a proper ſettlement, ſince ſhe is inclin'd to honour us with her alliance.—She cannot have had time to conſult her friends.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: No, truly, nor ever ſhall, with my conſent. Why, Jack, it is impoſſible you ſhou'd be ſo ignorant as you ſeem; you'll never be a rich man, that's certain. There are coups de maitres in trade, as well as love; and if a man has not courage to make a puſh, he will never make a fortune.—Conſult her friends, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: E. Free.
sp.p: I thought, ſir, when we parted, you had determined to act like an honeſt man, and deal upon the ſquare?

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Why, faith, Jack, you over-awed me then; but being at preſent a little more aſſur'd of ſucceſs, I laugh at your qualms, becauſe I am ſure that, by and by, you will laugh with me; and I ſhou'd deſerve to be eternally laugh'd at, if I were to be preach'd out of ſuch an opportunity of making my fortune; and ſo, my dear moral merchant, your moſt obedient, for I have ſcarce time to dreſs.

sp.speaker: E. Free.
sp.p: Incorrigible wretch! were I acquainted with the lady's name, I wou'd this moment alarm her family, and prevent her ruin. (looks at his watch) It is now near the time I am to meet Lord Belmont, upon buſineſs at his houſe; I cannot break my word; but that finiſhed, I will return, and watch every motion of this worthleſs brother, whom, if I can, (in ſpite of all the ties of blood) I will detect.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: What's to be done? A plague on that ſtupid, money-making brother.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Upon my word, ſir, I don't know what you'll do; they ſay it is too late to get ſix horſes for a journey, or even a fine chariot, to night.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Why did not you go ſooner?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Becauſe you ordered me to get your things to dreſs.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: 'Tis my own fault; why did I waſte my time with that dull fellow? But run, fly, try at the inns, get me even a poſt-chaiſe. Do any thing to make diſpatch.

I cou'd hang myſelf for being ſuch a negligent blockhead, to defer a thing of ſo much conſequence, 'till the laſt moment; if I ſhou'd loſe this night, 'tis ten to one but my evil genius, Jack, may take it into his head to deſcribe me as a fortune-hunter, in to-morrow's news-papers, and put Louiſa on her guard againſt me.
Have you ſucceeded? Have you got the chaiſe?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: No, ſir, but I have done much better. As your brother went out, I heard him ſay he had buſineſs with Lord Belmont, and older his chariot there.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Buſineſs there! and at this late hour!—no matter—he cannot gueſs my ſcheme.—He has ſome plodding accounts to ſettle in a hurry, perhaps, with his methodical lordſhip, which may be of uſe in detaining him from any chance of diſcovering what is going forward.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: True, ſir; now what I propoſe is this; I'll wait on your honour there, and take James with me, and decoy your brother's ſervants to the ale-houſe—treat them with plenty of liquor, while James drives the chariot round the houſe to the garden-door, and waits ready to whip away, when your honour and the lady come to him.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Bravo, Ralph.—Fortune ſeems inclined to befriend me, and my brother ſhall, at laſt, be a means of my ſucceſs, in ſpite of his mechanical morality.—Follow me.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Lord Belmont's library. Lord Belmont at a table, with papers before him.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: I am now ready for my banker. What a pleaſure there is in regularity! Yet many men, rather than take the trouble of ſettling their accounts, ſuffer their fortunes to moulder thro' their hands, without enjoyment, and ſcarce find themſelves in poſſeſſion of an eſtate before they feel the loſs of it. I have a noble ſurplus now for exigencies; I mean thoſe of others, more than my own. For the man, whoſe oeconomy is properly regulated, ſeldom feels the force of that ſharp word; and I would treaſure up my wealth in acts of liberality.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Mr. Southerne is come again to wait upon your lordſhip.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: Deſire him to walk in.
What can provoke him to return at this hour? I hoped he wou'd have allowed both himſelf and me to reſt this night.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: Finding myſelf comfortably refreſhed after my pipe and tankard, my lord, and John having informed me that the horſes are in good heart, and able to ſet out to-morrow; I thought it was as good to pay my reſpects to my brother and ſiſter Belmont, to night, as to loſe another day in compliments. Therefore, if you pleaſe, I'll wait on them directly, and take my leave.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: It ſhall be as you pleaſe, ſir; but I am ſurprized how you can think of leaving town, 'till you have found your daughter.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: Why, look'e, my lord, I am an old man, and have no time to loſe from the comforts of life. It is uncertain whether ever Emily may be found; and I want to get home to my own dear, who will nouriſh and cheriſh me. However, if you think there is any chance of finding my daughter, I don't much care if I ſtay one day longer.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: That is all I aſk, ſir.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: Well then, my lord, I will bide at your requeſt, and the horſes will be the better for it. And ſince I don't go out of town in the morning, if it is agreeable, I'll ſtay and ſup with your lordſhip.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: I am ſorry, ſir, I happen to be engaged, but am certain that Lady Bridget, and Mr. Belmont, will be glad of your company. I will acquaint them you are here, and return immediately to conduct you to them. [aſide] I muſt take care that Emily be not ſeen.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: What a deal of fuſs and ceremony is here? Cou'd not he let me go with him? But as he has no wife, may be he is gone to order ſomething for ſupper, as I uſed to do, when I was a widower. Ah! I wiſh I had continued ſo ſtill, and then I need not be afraid of any body! My nephew is a wiſe man, that's certain.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: I am ready now, ſir, to attend you; but muſt entreat you will not mention Emily's misfortune to my aunt or ſiſters.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: Come then, my lord; and ſince you deſire it, I will not.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter Lady Bridget, Lady Mary, and Lady Louiſa.

sp.speaker: L. Brid.
sp.p: I am doubtful whether I ſhall recollect Mr. Southerne; it is a good many years ſince I have ſeen him; and I was, at that aera, extremely young; in my infantine ſtate, as I may ſay.

div.stage: Enter Lord Belmont, and Mr. Southerne.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: Your ſervant, ſiſter; you look purely, faith; not a whit alter'd: my poor firſt wife was a great deal younger than you, and yet ſhe is gone: but we muſt all go, one time or other, they ſay.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: My ſiſters, ſir.—

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: Good pretty girls, my nieces are; the ſhorteſt of them is ſomething like my wife, when ſhe was her age; do you remember your aunt, young lady?

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: No, ſir; I don't believe I ever ſaw her.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: Perhaps not.—Well, Siſter Biddy, and are you jolly, old girl? You thrive rarely.

sp.speaker: L. Brid.
sp.p: Your phraſe is ſomewhat of the coarſeſt, Mr. Southerne.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: Why, yes, we all grow coarſe, as we grow old, to be ſure. I do remember when you were almoſt as ſlender as that young miſs there. But where's my brother Belmont, the philoſopher, as we us'd to call him? Is he poking after cockle-ſhells, and old bits of copper, ſtill, my lord?

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: My uncle, ſir, is true to his former taſte—but I ſuppoſe they have not acquainted him with your being here; I'll ſend to let him know it. You'll be ſo good as to excuſe me, ſir, as I am engag'd. Ladies, good night; I leave Mr. Southerne in your charge; pray take care of him.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: [aſide] He ſups abroad; that's lucky.

sp.speaker: L. Mar.
sp.p: What do you ſay, ſiſter?

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: Not material.

sp.speaker: L. Mar.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, have not you a daughter by my aunt? A very accompliſh'd young lady, I have heard my brother ſay.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: Yes, yes, madam, I have a daughter; and ſhe ought to be accompliſh'd, as you call it: ſhe has coſt me many a fair pound; ſhe was no leſs than ten years at a boarding-ſchool.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: Was not that rather too long, ſir, to let a young lady remain out of her father's houſe? She muſt have been a perfect ſtranger to you.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: Why, truly, madam, ſo ſhe was; but Mrs. Southerne ſaid it was for her good; and one muſt give up a great deal for the ſake of one's children, you know.

sp.speaker: L. Brid.
sp.p: I am ſurpriz'd, Mr. Southerne, you did not think proper to preſent Miſs Southerne's duty to me, nor her reſpects to theſe young ladies her couſins; in this you have certainly been deficient, ſir.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: Why, really, ſiſter, as neither you or they ever ſet eyes on her, I can't ſay I thought it of any great conſequence.

sp.speaker: L. Brid.
sp.p: Notwithſtanding our mutual misfortune in that caſe, ſir, proper decorum ſhou'd be obſerved. But I ſhall not on this occaſion enter into any conteſt of ſarcaſm, or reciprocation of ſmartneſs.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Brother Southerne, I am very glad to ſee you; how does my niece, and your wife, and all your children? Egad, you are a fine old Grecian, and wou'd make a very curious buſt; it might paſs for an antique; will you ſit to Ryſbrack for me?

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: As to the latter part of your diſcourſe, Brother Belmont, I don't thoroughly underſtand it; but as to my wife and children, they are very well; and I am glad to ſee you ſo.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Pray, Lady Mary, where is Miſs Lawſon?

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: In her chamber, ſir; I have not ſeen her ſome time.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I gueſſed it; ſome of ye have vexed her. I found her crying to day, ready to break her heart. I ſuppoſe this is your doings, Lady Bridget?

sp.speaker: L. Brid.
sp.p: Certainly my poor brother is ſeized with a delirium, to ſuppoſe it poſſible for me to tranſgreſs the laws of urbanity and hoſpitality in any inſtance.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: Surely, ſir, you muſt miſtake.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No, madam, I do not miſtake, I am in my ſenſes; tho' ſo many teizing contradicting women are enough to put a man beſide himſelf.

sp.speaker: L. Mar.
sp.p: Pray, Brother Belmont, who may this ſame lady be? I don't remember any of your family of that name.

sp.speaker: L. Brid.
sp.p: She is no way allied to us, ſir, either by affinity or conſanguinity.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You can't tell but ſhe may.

sp.speaker: L. Brid.
sp.p: You'll pardon me, brother, I do affirm ſhe is not of our family.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Then I do affirm ſhe is, for ſhe lives in the houſe; and ſhe may be nearer to you than you imagine.

sp.speaker: L. Brid.
sp.p: His ſenſes are quite gone.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: Faith, I think ſo; for he ſeems to me as if he had ſome thoughts of marrying.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: No, no, my dear uncle is not quite ſo mad, ſir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Don't be too ſure of that, my lady malapert; I hope I am old enough to take care of myſelf, without your advice or inſtruction, madam.

sp.speaker: L. Brid.
sp.p: Don't oppoſe his inſanity, irritation may augment it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: By Hercules Farneſe, Lady Bridget, if you don't leave off your tricks, you'll put me in a deviliſh paſſion; and you had better be quiet, let me tell you.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: For my part, I don't underſtand all this; I know not who is mad or ſober among ye; I think ye are all at a game of croſs purpoſes, and I wiſh I was ſafe in the country again.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Pleaſe your ladyſhip, ſupper is ſerved.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Is Miſs Lawſon in the parlour?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: No, ſir; ſhe is not well, and deſires to be excuſed.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh! now 'tis plain that you have made her ſick ſomehow or other among ye—but I'll go comfort her as ſoon as ſupper is over.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Enter Emily, with a book in her hand.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Reading's a charming exerciſe for minds at peace; books can even ſmooth affliction's furrow'd cheek, or change the ſource and channel of our tears, from ſelfiſh to humane; but when the mind is torn with doubts and fears, while mad contending paſſions labour in the breaſt, reaſon itſelf muſt fail to calm their diſcord; nor can the powers of eloquence or muſick attune the ſoul to peace or harmony.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: Emily, I thank you for the condeſcenſion you have ſhewn to my requeſt, unknowing of the cauſe.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Your lordſhip's commands were rather an indulgence, than a force upon my wiſhes; I therefore claim no merit from obedience.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: Your father is at preſent in this houſe, which will account to you for your confinement.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: My father in the houſe! Will you not ſuffer me to ſee him, ſir? O! let me fly to him, and give a looſe to that ſoft ſorrow that overpowers my heart.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: No, Emily; for a little time you have promis'd to be rul'd; I think you want not ſenſe or virtue to conduct yourſelf; but as I hope that by to-morrow we ſhall be able to clear up this dark ſcene which has perplex'd us, I wiſh you, for the preſent, to remain conceal'd: if my ſcheme ſhou'd fail, I then will give the reins into your hands, and ſuffer you to guide them.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: It is an office I do not wiſh for—by nature and by providence deſign'd, our helpleſs ſex's ſtrength lies in dependance; and where we are ſo bleſt to meet with generous natures, our ſervitude is empire: to ſuch a ſtate I once aſpir'd, but Somerville is gone; how loſt my hopes of happineſs!

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: Do not deſpair, Emily; you may poſſibly be nearer the completion of your wiſhes than you imagine; mean while, reſt aſſur'd of every thing, in the power of true friendſhip, to alleviate your diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: An honeſt heart, my lord, is always grateful; but when oppreſs'd with obligations, it may want the power of utterance; I cannot thank you, but I feel your kindneſs.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: My dear Emily, I am ſorry to leave you in this dejected mood; but I have two gentlemen to meet me upon buſineſs. I muſt therefore wiſh you a good night, and hope to-morrow's ſun will diſpel thoſe clouds that hang at preſent on your fame and mind.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Let the bright radiance of unerring truth ſhine forth on Emily's every thought and action; and pity, not reproach, will then attend her.

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: Enter Elder Freeman and a Servant.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I ſhall let my lord know you are here, ſir.

sp.speaker: E. Free.
sp.p: What an amiable man is Lord Belmont! I think no perſon ſo happily unites the man of buſineſs and the nobleman; nicely exact in all his dealings, yet generous as the moſt diſſipated and extravagant; liberality and oeconomy go hand in hand with him, and mutually ſupport each other.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: Your ſervant, Mr. Freeman; your accounts and mine agree exactly; I have look'd them over, the vouchers are all right: but I fear I have treſpaſs'd upon you, by deſiring to ſee you at an hour which men of buſineſs generally do, and always ought to give up to amuſement; but my being oblig'd to go into the country ſo immediately, will, I hope, plead my excuſe.

sp.speaker: E. Free.
sp.p:
I conſider my attendance on your lordſhip at any hour, as one of the rational pleaſures of a man
of buſineſs; as your converſation at once entertains and enlarges my mind.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: You are extremely polite, Mr. Freeman, and I ſhall be glad of every opportunity to cultivate the friendſhip of a perſon, whoſe dealings, as a man, and manners, as a gentleman, I ſo much eſteem. If you can ſpare a little time from buſineſs, I ſhall be very glad of the pleaſure of your company in Worceſterſhire.

sp.speaker: E. Free.
sp.p: I am extremely oblig'd to your lordſhip; but my father now growing infirm, his health requires a receſs from trouble and fatigue, and he paſſes moſt of the ſummer in the country; I therefore am confin'd.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: You have a brother tho', whoſe attendance, I ſhou'd imagine, might ſet you free—he is bred to buſineſs, I think?

sp.speaker: E. Free.
sp.p: Yes, my lord; but he is too fine a gentleman to follow it. The air of Lombard-ſtreet is too heavy for his conſtitution; he uſually reſides at this end of the town, has quitted buſineſs, and commenc'd fortune-hunter.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: [aſide] As I ſuſpected. I fear then, Mr. Freeman, he will make but a bad exchange; both a man's means and manners ſhou'd be ſuited to his ſituation, before he can poſſibly make a figure in it.

sp.speaker: E. Free.
sp.p: Nothing can be truer than your lordſhip's remark; but reaſon has no power over diſſipated minds, and experience alone can reclaim them: however, I will try once more to bring him back by argument.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: I heartily wiſh you ſucceſs, Mr. Freeman.

sp.speaker: E. Free.
sp.p: And I your lordſhip a good night.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: Your moſt obedient, ſir.

His brother certainly muſt be the man—How he cou'd poſſibly become acquainted with Louiſa, I can't conceive; but public places put every perſon on a level; and at ſome of theſe he muſt have ſeen her. To-morrow I will find this Freeman, and bring him to a ſevere account, both for Emily and Louiſa.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Diſcovers Lady Louiſa at her toilet, her Maid waiting.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: GIVE me that book, and then you may withdraw; I ſhall not want you again to-night. [Exit Maid.] What can keep Freeman? does he ſleep when his good ſtars and mine are all awake! It ſeems as if the god of love himſelf had interfer'd, and diſpos'd of the whole family in ſuch a way as to prevent all interruption.—In ſhort, there never was, nor will be ſuch a charming opportunity.
O, Mr. Freeman! what cou'd tempt you to ſuch a dangerous act of indiſcretion? I ſhall be totally ruin'd if you ſhou'd be diſcovered.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Fear nothing, my angel, I will protect you from all danger; this happy night I ſhall become your guardian, and all my future life ſhall be devoted to your ſervice.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: This night, did you ſay, Mr. Freeman? How is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: If you conſent to bleſs me with your hand, we may eſcape this moment: I did not hear a creature in the houſe; they are all retired to reſt; then do not loſe this lucky criſis, but fly to love and happineſs this moment.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: It will be deem'd ſo raſh a ſtep, I fear my brother never will forgive me.—Had we not better aſk his conſent?

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: [aſide] I muſt parry that ſtroke.—What are brothers, fathers, mothers, ſiſters, uncles, or aunts, to love? They might perhaps poſtpone our happineſs for ſettlements, and ſuch dull ſtuff; for I can aſſure your ladyſhip, there wou'd be no fear of a refuſal—the family of Freeman—

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: I have no doubt but my friends wou'd be extremely pleaſed with your alliance, ſir; and for that reaſon, wiſh we had conſulted them.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Why, ſo do I, ſince you ſeem now to deſire it; but, oh! my charmer, think what I muſt ſuffer by the leaſt delay? then let me gently preſs you to be mine; my chariot's at the garden-door.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: I know not how to conſent, or to deny.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Dear, lovely angel, do not torture me, nor tear my faithful heart, with doubts and fears; you muſt, you ſhall be mine.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: What will the world ſay of me?

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Say, that you had love, generoſity, and ſpirit, to truſt a man of honour: but why will you thus waſte the precious minutes?

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: I find you can perſuade me to any thing.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Generous creature! now let us fly.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: Ha! there's my ſiſter going to her chamber, which overlooks the garden; we muſt not ſtir, 'till ſhe is in bed. Step into the next room, as it is poſſible ſhe may come here.
sp.stage: [Exit Y. Freeman. Louiſa ſits at her toilet reading.

sp.speaker: L. Mar.
sp.p: What are you reading, Louiſa?

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: Pope's Homer, ſiſter.

sp.speaker: L. Mar.
sp.p: Then you have no mind to compoſe yourſelf to reſt, I perceive; the loftineſs of the ſubject, and elegance of the language, will be apt to rouſe your attention, and keep you awake.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: I am vaſtly ſleepy, notwithſtanding that.

sp.speaker: L. Mar.
sp.p: Then I will not treſpaſs on your repoſe, tho' I am unaccountably wakeful.—Shall I go with you to your chamber?

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: No, ſiſter, I'll go with you to yours.

sp.speaker: L. Mar.
sp.p: Come then, and if you have any good nature, you'll chat to me, while I undreſs.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p:
Poor Charles!—at laſt he is gone—what difficulty have I had in perſuading him to ſeek for the
only relief his preſent ſituation can admit of—reſt.—In ſome few hours, I hope his paſſions will be as much rais'd with joy, as they are now depreſs'd by anxiety; for, as I can have no doubt of Emily's conduct, or his honour, they muſt yet be happy. [A noiſe of laughing.] By that ſound, I perceive that jolly threeſcore are ſtill at their bottle, perhaps they are in the right; age ſhou'd enjoy, or rather catch each paſſing moment of delight; youth ſhou'd huſband time, and ſpend it ſparingly; the ſpirit, not the lees of life, is worth preſerving
I hope you have met no accident to bring you back, Sir Charles?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: I ſcarce have breath to tell you.—Paſſing again by your garden-door, I ſaw it ſtand open, and at a little diſtance, a chariot: I aſked the coachman who he waited for? he ſaid Mr. Freeman; he is this moment, in your houſe, my lord, upon ſome clandeſtine purpoſe.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: You have amazed me; but let us act with caution, nor truſt my ſervants with my ſiſters honour—to one of them he comes. O Charles, this is a heavy trial.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: It may not be ſo bad as you imagine; your own maxim is, to hope the beſt.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: We are all philoſophers, when others ſuffer, but tremblingly alive to our own feelings. I'll go, this moment, and ſearch every apartment. Do you place yourſelf upon the center of the ſtair-caſe, and lock the folding doors—if the villain ſhou'd fly from me, you muſt meet him. But remember, Sir Charles, he is accountable to me this night, to-morrow he may anſwer you.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p:
Was there ever any creature ſo teizing, as Lady Mary? I really believe, if I had ſtaid with
her, ſhe wou'd have continued talking 'till morning. It is amazing that ſhe don't go to bed. I dare not let Mr. Freeman out, 'till I think ſhe is aſleep. Bleſs me, what noiſe is this?

sp.speaker: L. Mar.
sp.p: O Louiſa, my brother is this moment running from room to room, and ſearching every corner with his ſword drawn, and a wildneſs in his countenance, not to be expreſs'd: I am terrified to death.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: I am undone! Freeman is in my chamber.

sp.speaker: L. Mar.
sp.p: What ſhall we do? There may be murder if they meet.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: I cannot ſpeak, or think.

sp.speaker: L. Mar.
sp.p: Let him fly down the back ſtairs.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: It muſt be ſo, there is no other way.—Do you return to your chamber.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: A paſſage, with a chamber-door ſhut.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: The ſtair-caſe door is lock'd, there's no retreating. If I cou'd get into any of the rooms on the middle floor, I wou'd leap out of the window, and hazard my neck, rather than bear to be expos'd. I hear Lord Belmont's voice, I'll force this door, at all events.
Ha! what has conjur'd up the only form, that at this moment cou'd encreaſe my terror?

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Is it an apparition that I ſee! Defend me gracious heaven!

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Dear madam, don't be alarmed; upon my knees I beg you will protect me; my life's at ſtake, and what is dearer ſtill, a lady's honour.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Inhuman wretch! you have already robb'd me of all that was moſt precious, my lover and my fame; I have now nothing but my life to loſe, and you may take it freely.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p:
By heaven, madam, I never deſign'd you the leaſt injury; and if you have the ſmalleſt grain
of compaſſion, you will aſſiſt me to eſcape. I am abſolutely ruin'd if you don't, and ſo is Lady Louiſa.—Is there no way to get out?

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Thou worſe than murderer! do not profane a lady's name, that I am certain knows you not; but if you have the leaſt compunction for all the ſorrows you have brought on me, ſay why you haunt me thus?

div.stage: Enter Lord Belmont, Lady Mary, and Lady Louiſa.

sp.speaker: L. Bel
sp.p: Now ladies, this affair muſt be explain'd.—Who are you, ſir, that have thus broke into my houſe, at midnight, and taken refuge in this lady's chamber?

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: I'm at my laſt puſh; there is but one way. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: This moment ſpeak, who are you?

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: A gentleman, my lord, but one, I muſt confeſs, who, tempted by ſtrong paſſion, has infring'd that juſt reſpect, which is your lordſhip's due, by entering your houſe without your knowledge: but love, my lord.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: Of whom? declare that, inſtantly.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: [aſide] Now I'm undone.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Your lordſhip will, I hope, excuſe my mentioning the lady, as ſhe is equally involv'd in this unlucky accident.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: No trifling, ſir; explain yourſelf this moment.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: [aſide] Sure 'tis a viſion! no, it is my Emily.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Will nothing, ſir, avail, to ſave the lady's honour?

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: Nothing ſhall ſave your life, ſir, but a fair confeſſion.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Why then, my lord, I muſt own, tho' very unwillingly upon my honour, that I came hither by this lady's appointment.

sp.speaker: Sir Char
sp.p: 〈◊〉 my fears are true, and I can hold no longer. [comes forward] Ungrateful woman.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Good heaven! this is too much.
sp.stage: [Faints. L. Louiſa, and Lady Mary carry her off.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: This is lucky, however. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: I am ſtruck dumb with wonder.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: [aſide] What the devil has brought him here?—Your lordſhip ſees how much you have diſtreſs'd the lady, by preſſing her to own her paſſion; ladies are apt to be baſhful, when there are ſtrangers by.—Perhaps Sir Charles may not know me. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: I beg, my lord, you will inform me.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: Pray, Somerville, be calm; at a proper time, I ſhall ſatisfy all your enquiries about Emily.— [To Freeman.] I have one queſtion more to aſk you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: I am ready to anſwer with the ſame truth, my lord.—Egad, I ſhall come off with flying colours. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: Were not you in this houſe about ſeven this evening?

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Why, as a man of honour, my lord, I can't poſſibly tell a lye; I was here about that time, but the lady was then afraid of being diſcovered, and deſired me to come at this hour, when we concluded the family wou'd be at reſt.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: I am ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Why then, my lord, I beg leave to wiſh you, and the ladies, a very good night, and aſk a thouſand pardons for diſturbing your lordſhip's repoſe.— [Going]

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: [aſide] He has brought me off triumphantly, but I muſt ſee the event.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Stay, ſir, I have yet ſomething to ſay to you.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Well, ſir, pray what are your commands?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: In that light you are to underſtand them, ſir, for they ſhall be obey'd.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: You'll pleaſe to be as brief as you can, ſir, for it grows late.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p:
That I have lov'd that wretched, hapleſs Emily, I need not now inform you; I have no doubt,
but ſhe has already gratified your vanity, by boaſting of the ſacrifice ſhe made, however worthleſs ſhe herſelf might think it.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Upon my honour, ſir, the lady never mention'd your name to me in her life.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: No interruption, nor evaſion, ſir, they can't avail. Fallen as ſhe is at preſent, in my eſteem, I will ſtill, as far as ſhe has left it poſſible, preſerve her ſame; you muſt marry her immediately, ſir.

sp.speaker: L Loui.
sp.p: Ha! what can this mean?

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: You are not in earneſt, ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Quite determined.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: You muſt excuſe me, ſir—You do me honour.—But I have particular reaſons—which, at preſent, I cannot ſo well explain.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: [draws] Villain, defend yourſelf.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: [interpoſes] Not in this houſe, Sir Charles; I muſt not ſuffer it.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: No place ſhou'd be a ſanctuary for ſuch a monſter.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Belmont and Mr. Southerne.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why, what the devil's the matter here! if you are for a bout of tilting, have with you, I'll be on the weaker ſide.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: I ſay, what's the matter? I am a magiſtrate, and command the peace in the king's name.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: [To Free.] We are prevented now; but if you do not chuſe to join the name of coward to that of villain, I ſhall expect to hear from you to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, hear me now.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: Why, hey! what the devil is this? Here are the two fellows that ran away with my daughter; they ſhall give an account of her directly; who knows but they have murder'd her. I command you all to aſſiſt me to apprehend them.

div.stage: Enter Emily, and falls at Mr. Southerne's feet.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Behold that wretched daughter at your feet, murder'd, indeed, in her loſt peace and fame; but ſtill alive to filial tenderneſs. O Somerville!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why, Miſs Lawſon, what do you kneel to him for? get up, my pretty creature, and come to your own love; don't cry, don't cry.—Juſt as ſhe ſtands now, ſhe wou'd make a pretty model for a ſmall Niobe.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: No, don't cry, child, and I'll make one of them, at leaſt, marry you, or I'll hang them both.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Neither of them ſhall have her; I'll marry her myſelf.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: What, marry your niece, brother Belmont? Why don't you know Emily is my daughter?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: None of your ſhams to me, I won't believe a word of it.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: [To Freeman.] Have you had leiſure, ſir, to make your option, whether you will accept this lady for your wife, or vindicate your refuſal with your ſword?

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: What can you mean, my lord, why am I offer'd to that deteſted wretch? No power on earth ſhall force me to be his.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Well acted, madam, but the farce is done.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: You hear, my lord, that the lady abſolutely refuſes, you would not be ſo cruel to compel her.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: Ay, but I ſay I will compel her and you too; I'll have no more plague with her: this was the way ſhe ſerv'd me about Winterbottom; I wiſh I had made her marry him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
Egad, I begin to think ſhe is his daughter; and if that be the caſe, ſhe ſhall get a huſband.—Do you hear, you hatchet-face gentleman, that are very like my worſt medal of Nero, if you don't marry my niece directly, you ſhall have a couple of ounces of
lead in your ſtomach for breakfaſt, inſtead of your coffee to-morrow-morning; that is, if ſhe ſays you promis'd her marriage; but if not, you are at liberty to go about your buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: I dare appeal, ſir, to the lady's truth and honour; if ſhe ſays I ever promis'd to marry her, I am ready to do ſo this moment.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why that's fair enough.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: I ſay right or wrong, nolens volens, he ſhall marry her.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Pray, madam, ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Though your inhuman artifices have undone me, I claim no promiſe from you, and call on heaven to witneſs, that 'till within this hour I never ſpoke to you, nor ſaw your face but once, 'till this unhappy night, in my whole life.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: This is amazing!

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: By heaven ſhe does not bluſh! Sure, madam, you forget that I ſtand here. Is it not enough that you are ſunk in my eſteem? But will you teach me to deſpiſe myſelf, for having ever lov'd a woman that can be capable of ſuch mean, ſuch unavailing falſhood?

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Sir Charles, I pity more than blame you.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Inſolent generoſity! But I diſclaim your pity; keep it, madam, for yourſelf, leſt you ſhould miſs it elſewhere.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, don't ſcold my niece ſo; I don't ſee how ſhe has deſerv'd it from you.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: O Somerville! is it poſſible you yet can doubt my innocence?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: No, madam, I have no doubts; but beg you'll not profane a term that is your ſex's brighteſt ornament—your innocence!

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p:
Come, gentlemen, all this talk ſignifies nothing; one or other of ye muſt marry my daughter, that's certain. You have acquitted this gentleman, child; now what have you to ſay to the other? I can
ſafely ſwear he promiſed to marry you, for he aſked my conſent.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: If that be the caſe, I ſhall diſcourſe him preſently.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: Come, don't be afraid to ſpeak, child; I am in a very good humour now; and if you have a mind for that ſame knight, before George he ſhall marry you, or I'll hamper him at law, that I will.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: You are ſo kind to promiſe, ſir, you will confirm my option.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: Ay, that I will, here's my hand for it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And here's mine too, niece (tho' I am ſorry to call you ſo) that no man alive ſhall uſe you ill while I am able to draw a trigger, if it was only for ſake of that love I had for you, when I had a mind to be nearer related to you.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: [To Sir Charles.] I cannot gueſs where this will end.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: I am all impatience.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Tho' it muſt call a bluſh into a virgin's cheek, to own her love, before ſo many witneſſes, yet as it is the only declaration of this kind, that I ſhall ever make, I will confeſs, that dearer than my life or fame, I love Sir Charles Somerville,

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Confuſion! Belmont, what can ſhe intend?

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Pray hear me out, the difficulty's paſt: I have avowed my love: but were that man, whom my heart owns its lord, to ſue with all his former tenderneſs and paſſion, to obtain my hand, not worlds ſhou'd bribe me to beſtow it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: [aſide] That's very odd, tho'.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p:
While in his heart there cou'd remain a ſingle doubt of my truth or honour; and as my injur'd fame is now obſcured, all I requeſt, is, that you will permit me to retire to ſome diſtant part of the world, where my unhappy ſtory is not known, and where my name may never bring diſgrace upon my family;
this, ſir, is my ſole requeſt, and you have promiſed me to grant it.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: O Belmont, ſhe has torn my heart! but yet conviction cannot lye, my eyes, my ears, are witneſs of her falſhood.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: By Jupiter Ammon, you ſha'n't go into any loneſome place, you ſhall live with me.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: [To Emily.] Madam, the kind confeſſion you have made, at leaſt deſerves my thanks, and I am truly ſorry your conduct ſhou'd have contradicted it ſo far, as to make them the ſole return I can with honour offer.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: [aſide] I begin to feel unhappy about this girl; I cou'd almoſt recant—but what becomes of Louiſa, then?

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Had my reſentment and reſolves left it in your power to have ſhewn gratitude, in any other way, you never ſhou'd have known your obligation.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: Still more and more myſterious. [To Sir Charles.] I know not what to think; but, let her faults be what they may, ſhe carries her puniſhment in her own breaſt, and bears it nobly.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: [To L. Belmont.] I am diſtreſs'd, beyond all meaſure; I cannot ſtand this ſcene. [To Emily.] Madam, my ardent wiſhes for your happineſs, tho' with as little hopes of their ſucceſs, as thoſe I may beſtow upon my own, ſhall ſtill be yours—at preſent, I am ſure, I rather increaſe, than leſſen your diſtreſs, I therefore take my leave.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Adieu, for ever!

div.stage: Enter Lady Louiſa, and Lady Mary.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: Stay, ſir! though I were ſure to forfeit as much happineſs as Emily deſerves to poſſeſs, I cou'd not think of ſaving it at her expence.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: [To Lady Louiſa.] Speak, madam, quickly ſpeak.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p:
You muſt allow me time; I have a ſevere taſk to go through; and firſt muſt own myſelf unworthy
of the moſt unbounded confidence, that a kind brother ever yet beſtowed, or a raſh girl abus'd.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: [aſide] Sure the devil won't tempt her to betray herſelf!

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: Speak without fear, Louiſa, and be aſſur'd your motives for this generous confeſſion already have excus'd you.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: Shou'd even the loſs of your eſteem, my lord, attend the knowledge of my fault, I cannot bear that innocence ſhou'd ſuffer, and therefore will avow it. That gentleman [points to Freeman] came here this night to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: [aſide] I ſhall have my throat cut, that I ſee plainly.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: By your appointment, ſiſter; who did he come to in the afternoon?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Aye, my lord, what brought him hither, at that time? This is what ladies call a pious fraud of friendſhip.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Equally inclin'd to clear that lady's character, tho' not equally involved in the conſequences, I own that I was acquainted with his viſit at that time. Your lordſhip may remember my confuſion, when you came up this evening.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Is the man bewitch'd? Did he court all my nieces, and won't marry any of them? I'll fight him with three caſe of piſtols.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: I am in a ſtound, Brother Belmont; I don't underſtand all this.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: I do remember that you ſeem'd diſtreſs'd, but pray was it to you he came?[To Lady Mary.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: No, my lord, it was tome. Speak, Mr. Freeman, you have often told me your family and fortune might claim me for your wife; are you aſhamed of your attachment to me?

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: O, by no means, madam, tho' I may appear a little aukward at preſent.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: You ſee my brother is ready to forgive my folly, in carrying on a match clandeſtinely, that I might have own'd with honour; but indeed, my lord, it was my own romance, tho' I think Mr. Freeman has acquieſced rather too far.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Why, to be ſure, ma'am, it was entirely to gratify your ladyſhip's humour, that I did not at firſt apply to my lord.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: I have confeſs'd it, ſir.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: But ſince matters have taken this odd, ridiculous turn, I think it will be the beſt way to let my lawyer wait upon his lordſhip in the morning with my rent-roll; your ladyſhip ſhall have a carte blanche, I aſſure you, quite the ſame as if this affair had never happen'd. [Aſide.] Egad, I wiſh I was fairly out of the houſe.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: [aſide] Inſolent puppy!

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: As matters ſeem now to be upon a proper footing, I think it will not be amiſs if I retire.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Hold, ſir, did not I find you in this lady's cloſet [points to Emily] one night at Bath? You did not come to Lady Louiſa there?

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: Ha! this I am quite a ſtranger to!

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: [aſide] Egad, it is all out now. Why, ſir, that this lady and I have met before is moſt certain.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Good heaven! can you perſiſt in ſuch inhuman falſhood?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: O, 'tis quite clear, and this affair of Lady Louiſa's is all pretence, my lord.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: 'Tis not unlikely, I may be deceiv'd. [To Emily.] You ſhou'd have own'd your acquaintance with Mr. Freeman ſooner, madam, and not ſuffer'd me to expoſe myſelf, by trying to ſave your character, which is already loſt.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Do not inſult her, ſiſter; if ſhe is innocent, it is a crime; if guilty, ſhe has load enough to bear.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: My lord, the gentleman who was with you, upon buſineſs to night, deſires to be admitted to you upon a very particular occaſion.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: Bid him walk in.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Muſt my diſgrace be made the common topic, and I the public gaze? Let me retire, my lord.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: No, Emily, I intreat your ſtay for a few minutes, perhaps this gentleman may be of uſe.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: I have no right, my lord, to hope relief from ſtrangers, when love and friendſhip have abandon'd me. Yet I will ſtay, if you deſire it; for grief like mine is patient.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: [aſide] Nay, then the devil does owe me a ſpite, and is reſolv'd to pay it.

sp.speaker: E. Free.
sp.p: By the confuſion I read in my brother's face, my lord, I begin to think that my preſence is unneceſſary to his detection. But I beg the honour of ſpeaking a word or two to your lordſhip apart.
sp.stage: [They retire to the ſide of the ſcene.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: His brother! 'Tis I that ſhall become the public topic now.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: Hey day! Brother Belmont, what new adventure is going to open on us now?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: [To Lady Mary.] I ſuppoſe this gentleman muſt be your humble ſervant, Lady Mary.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: I am infinitely indebted to your friendſhip, ſir. Sir Charles, this gentleman has confirmed what Louiſa has before confeſſed. What is your opinion now?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: I know not what to think, I am diſtracted; but ſtill that Bath affair dwells on my mind, and weighs down all my hopes.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p:
Why, then, ſir, ſince Mr. John Freeman has thought proper to expoſe me before Lady Louiſa, and that I have no farther hopes of recovering her
favour, I will, without reſerve, eaſe your mind and my own, by diſcovering the whole truth.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: Do that, ſir, and you may find a friend, where you had reaſon to expect an enemy.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: Ay, do, pray tell us how that ſame buſineſs came about.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, do not keep me longer on the rack.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: I muſt have time to bluſh a little before Lady Louiſa, madam, as I may poſſibly appear in her eyes a moſt unworthy wretch.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: Nothing that you can ſay, ſir, will alter my opinion of you, or remove the contempt I feel for myſelf; ſo pray proceed.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Well, madam, [to Emily] the ſtory is but ſhort. You had a very pretty maid at Bath.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: A bold, pert ſlut; Mrs. Southerne never liked her.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: But I did, ſir, nor was ſhe in the leaſt cruel; and by her appointment I was paſſing thro' your chamber into hers, at the very inſtant that gentleman [points to Sir Charles] and you came into the room. She puſhed me into your cloſet, ſhut the door, and vaniſhed. The reſt you know too well.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: How cou'd you, ſir, be ſo inhuman, to let my Emily ſuffer? O Belmont, I dare not look upon her.

sp.speaker: Y. Free.
sp.p: Sir Charles, had your paſſion ſuffered you to have aſked me then my errand, I ſhou'd have frankly own'd it; but while I had hopes of Lady Louiſa. I could not, with any decency, have revealed theſe laſt particulars. And now, that I have done all in my power to ſet matters to rights, and atone my faults, I can only, in palliation of my behaviour, ſay, that it was not badneſs of heart, but diſlike to a ſedentary life, which tempted me to leave my ſphere, and ſoar at higher objects. In which, I am now ſenſible, I have juſtly failed; and muſt encounter the deſerved fate of thoſe, whom vanity ſeduces from the ſituation of life provided for them.

sp.speaker: E. Free.
sp.p: The daring to confeſs we have been wrong, is not only the higheſt act of bravery, but the beſt ſecurity for our future amendment; and thus reclaim'd, I am proud to embrace my brother.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: But what is all this to my poor child's character, that had like to be ruined by you, and that impudent baggage?

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: O, ſir, I am too happy to have my conduct cleared, both to the world and you! And yet, how gladly wou'd I now recall the fond confeſſion, which diſtraction wrung from my weak, ſinking heart, and now o'erwhelms me with bluſhes and confuſion.

sp.speaker: L. Loui.
sp.p: You have no cauſe to bluſh; it is for weakneſs, ſuch as mine, to ſink under my own reproach.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: You are both too rigid to yourſelves; but there is one who well deſerves your pity, becauſe he fears to aſk it.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: I do not, my lord, preſume to aſk for Emily's forgiveneſs, nor dare I form a hope that ſhe ſhou'd grant it.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Sir Charles, I do not wiſh to triumph over your humility, but beg you will allow me to indulge my own generoſity, by aſſuring you, that thro' this whole affair I never once condemned, but pitied your miſtake.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: My generous Emily!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why, what is all this about? If you like my niece, why don't you come and take her, and her pity, and her pardon together, and I'll give you a good five thouſand pounds into the bargain. Come, brother, give her hand to Sir Charles, and let's make an end of it.

sp.speaker: South.
sp.p: With all my heart, brother, if they are both willing, for I promiſed my lord to give my conſent.

sp.speaker: L. Bel.
sp.p: Now, Emily, it reſts on you alone, to ſhew that noble minds moſt eaſily forgive.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p:
I have been only on the defenſive, my lord, during this whole warfare; and ſuch an enemy is generally
ready for terms of peace; therefore if you ſhou'd hold out the olive branch in my name, to your ally, you may ſuppoſe I ſhall accede to the treaty.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: No words can ſpeak my gratitude; my heart's too full for utterance. Tranſporting charmer! every way you have conquer'd, ſubdued me, by eſteem, as well as love.

l.hi: From theſe events, the innocent may know,
That ſuffering is the lighteſt part of woe;
While our own conduct vindicates from blame,
Slander defeated, but augments our fame.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.stage: Spoken by Miſs WILFORD, in the character of Lady LOUISA.

lg.l: I Had an Epilogue to ſpeak to night,
But I'm ſo hurried, put in ſuch a fright,
Deuce take me!—if I ha'nt forgot it quite.
To ſee my name in firſt night's play-bill printed,
A character quite new, in time quite ſtinted;
An Epilogue, beſides, to get by heart,
'Tis moſt unmerciful, too long a part—
But they ſo coax'd and wheedled me to duty,
Leſt I ſhould fret—for fretting ſpoils one's beauty,
That, in obedience to the kind command,
A ſuppliant to your favour, here I ſtand:
And hope, inſtead of what had been prepar'd,
Some nonſenſe of my own, may now be heard.
Well! I have had a great eſcape, I own,
From being made the jeſt of all the town;
For from the court end I could claim no pity,
Nor had I more to hope for, from the city;
Such matches rarely anſwer either ſide,
For induſtry is ſuited ill with pride.
But, to divert your cenſure, let me ſhew
A folly more compleat, a city beau!
What contraſt can there be ſo ſtrong in nature,
As Engliſh plainneſs apeing petit-maître!
And yet poor I, by miſſing ſuch a lover,
May wait, 'till all my dancing days are over!
Next, ſhift the ſcene—behold a virtuoſo!
An old illiterate, feeble amoroſo!
What weakneſs can the human heart diſcover,
More ſhameful, than a climacteric lover?
Men, who have turn'd the period of threeſcore,
Become mere virtuoſo's—in amour.
Nor does Aunt Bridget merit better quarter,
Who, ſcorning to abide by female charter,
Invades a province, to our ſex deny'd,
Aiming at knowledge with a pedant's pride;
When, after all our boaſt, we find, at length,
To know our weakneſs is our ſureſt ſtrength,
One path of ſcience only, wiſe men ſay,
Is left for female learning—to obey.—
If characters like theſe your mirth excite,
And furniſh ſome amuſement for the night,
If nought offend the maxims of the ſtage,
Or ſhock the nicer morals of the age,
If only venial errors here you find,
Critics be dumb—ye men of candour, kind.
